Subject: Re: [neat] Merging species...

X-Yahoo-Profile: alienseedpod

Just a couple of quick words. I like the idea of the gradual merging in 
of structure from a side species as opposed to a single merge event. It 
'feels' more natural but I suppose that depends on the precise way you 
do it. E.g. if you keep merging while the target species is improving or 
until a stagnation threshold (no improvements for N gens) has passed 
then how much merging you do dynamically adjusts. A 'one-event' merge 
could be made to do this as well though I suppose.

Also this merging idea makes me think of bacteria exchanging genes that 
code for certain proteins. For example a strain of staphylococcus can 
become resistant to beta-lactam antibiotics by a mutation that causes 
beta-lactamase production. However this can take some time and a large 
population to achieve. Now if after drug resitance has evolved a second 
strain without resistance co-exists with the first it can aquire 
resistance relatively quickly because -  as I understand it anyway - 
some bacteria have a tendency to leave bits of DNA/RNA lying around 
(e.g. that codes for beta-lactamase) and other bacteria even of 
different strains can hoover up these chunks of DNA and incorporate them 
into their own genetic code.

I suppose an analogue in NEAT would be if we had two seperate 
modular-NEAT populations and they randomly exchanged modules from time 
to time.

Colin.
